title: Mathematical psychologists should preregister more studies
text:
Abstracts
Math Psych: Mathematical psychologists should preregister more studies

Because many strong theories make clear predictions, in principle there is no advantage to registering such a theory’s predictions in advance of collecting data (Szollosi & Donkin, 2021). On that basis, some researchers have argued that preregistration is not worthwhile – the priority should be on developing strong theories (Szollosi et al., 2020). Unfortunately, however, the psychological literature has not done this. What is the solution? I will argue that preregistration is, ironically, an important part of the answer. Both old and new strong theories that make correct predictions have difficulty attracting the recognition that they deserve. One factor that contributes to this is the scarcity of both the skills and the time required to determine that a theory is strong and makes clear predictions. A second factor is the tragic failure of psychologists to appreciate strong theories. Both factors can be addressed by preregistering more studies, in part because everyone recognizes the value of correct predictions. Finally, while I claim that preregistration is important, it

title: Mathematical psychologists should preregister more studies
text:
Math psychs
“There is also little reason to expect that preregistration will spontaneously help researchers to develop better theories”

title: Mathematical psychologists should preregister more studies
text:
The argument


Preregistration guards against researcher degrees of freedom 
Strong theories do not have researcher degrees of freedom 
Therefore: Preregistration is redundant

title: Mathematical psychologists should preregister more studies
text:
The argument


Preregistration guards against researcher degrees of freedom 
Strong theories do not have researcher degrees of freedom
Therefore: Preregistration is redundant



Fixing the argument

title: Mathematical psychologists should preregister more studies
text:
The argument


Preregistration guards against researcher degrees of freedom 
Strong theories do not have degrees of freedom
Therefore: Preregistration is redundant



So, preregistration is not redundant. However, to the extent that math psych theories have fewer degrees of freedom, preregistration seems less useful. However, there is another reason to preregister!

title: Mathematical psychologists should preregister more studies
text:
Weaker, but better argument


Preregistration guards against researcher degrees of freedom 
Strong theories have FEWER degrees of freedom
Therefore: Preregistration is LESS important for strong theories

So, those with strong theories shouldn’t bother preregistering




This weaker version still may result in a lot of math psychs not preregistering

title: Mathematical psychologists should preregister more studies
text:
But there’s another problem in psychology.

 Very few are making strong theories (Szollosi & Donkin; 2019; Szollosi & Donkin, 2021).

Hm, it seems they don’t value theory development enough

title: Mathematical psychologists should preregister more studies
text:
A different benefit of preregistration
While few d.f. means preregistration has less benefit for guarding against d.f., preregistration has other benefits.
God can instantly determine that a theory is strong and makes precise predictions with few auxiliary assumptions.
Humans need time.

The kind of theory that preregistration is least needed for the most well-known benefit is why
